# Definition and aim

The Heat Stress Scale (HSS) aims at enhancing community resilience to heatwave disasters. 
The HSS consists of four stratified risk categories (low, moderate, high, and extreme). 

## More about the scale
The HSS provides a simple interpretation of the current and forecasted heat stress risk.
It does so by using outdoor air temperature, humidity, solar radiation, and wind speed. 
These parameters are obtained from the [Norwegian Meteorological Institute](https://www.met.no/).
Environmental parameters are then combined with personal parameters and used as an input in a physiological human thermoregulation model.

The approach used to calculate and interpret thermal balance is based on the most recent findings in science. 
Further developments regarding the computation of the various terms in the heat balance equation or their interpretation will be considered as they become available.
This model estimates the risk of overheating and dehydration and associated negative health effects.

This tool evaluates the risk for a typical individual.
Consequently, it cannot accurately estimate the exact risk encountered by every single individual.
For this reason, this application is intended for informational use only.
It is not intended to provide medical advice or replace professional medical judgment, diagnosis, or treatment. 

## Disclaimer and User Agreement

It visualises meteorological data form the [Norwegian Meteorological Institute](https://www.met.no/) and calculates heat stress risk using a thermophysiological model.

No personally identifiable information is collected or stored. 
All data is treated as confidential and is securely stored in compliance with applicable data protection regulations. 
We do not sell or share any data with third parties.
By using this application, you agree to the collection and use of data as described in this statement.
